course.title: Introduction to Women's and Gender Studies

description.div: Personal, interpersonal and institutional dimensions of women's experiences from a variety of perspectives.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

notes.div: University Honors Seminar 189H is required of all students in the University Honors Program.

description.div: Topic varies.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs of sociology or related social sciences

description.div: Examination of how gender matters in the social world. Introduction to sociological theories about gender and related research. Â Considers how lifelong gender socialization, social institutions, norms, laws, and cultural practices create gendered effects in every aspect of life.

course.title: Introduction to Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans-gender, Queer/Sexuality Studies

description.div: Interdisciplinary issues related to sexuality and gender, both historical and contemporary.

course.title: Women and Gender in U.S. History

description.div: Survey of women's experiences and gender relations in American history from 1500 to present.

notes.div: A service learning project is part of WMNS 210.

description.div: Intersection of service learning and activism with feminist theories.

course.title: Introduction to Lesbian and Gay Literature

description.div: Introduction to variety of works by lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender writers. Significant literary, cultural, social, and historical issues and themes.
Introduction to English literature written by women, studies in the cultural, social, and/or historical contexts.
For course description, see PHIL 218.

Survey of the role and status of women within Western societies from ancient Greece and Rome to contemporary America, with the major focus upon nineteenth- and twentieth-century developments. Primary emphasis on analysis of the evolution of the position of women in society within the context imposed by cultural milieu, level of technological development, political and economic structure, family structure, and social class.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs of sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Overview of the sociological study of families. Family and marriage patterns over time. Socialization, economic exchange, and social support functions of family roles. The effect of the economy, public policy, and other social institutions on families.Â Emphasis on gender, sexuality, social class, and racial/ethnic diversity in U.S families.

course.title: Sex and Gender Around the Globe

description.div: Issues of gender through global lenses. Investigate the roles gender plays in complex issues of migration, war, global economics, education, food, water, transport, family integrity, security, and several other global issues. How femininity, masculinity and sexuality shape these questions as well as how these issues affect local communities.

course.title: Introduction to Poetry Writing: Women's Poetry

notes.div: ENGL/WMNS 253A may not be offered every year.

description.div: Introduction to the writing of poetry. Emphasis on student writing with special focus on reading women poets and on issues that concern women writers.

course.title: Exploring Love, Sexuality and Femininity in the History of Arabic Culture

description.div: Concepts of love, sexuality and femininity as studied in their historical, religious and sociological contexts.

course.title: Special Topics in Women's & Gender Studies

description.div: Topics vary.
A diachronic approach to Quran as a literature. Provides an analytic, linguistic as well as the critical study of both the Qurâanic text and its exegeses.

notes.div: ENGL/WMNS 315A may not be offered every year.

description.div: Historical survey of women's writings in English.
Relation between women's roles and popular images in the media, including romances, television shows, science fiction, and magazines, with attention to their historical development.

prerequisite.div: 6 hrs sociology or related social sciences

description.div: In-depth examination of select contemporary issues confronting families and family research. Adolescent pregnancy, union formation, parenting, work-family, divorce and family instability, and family violence. Topics vary by instructor.

Survey of women in European history from the Middle Ages to the present. Themes include power relations, work, love and sexuality, marriage, legal issues for women, and growth of feminist consciousness.
Image of the madwoman throughout European and American history. Emphasis on how women on the margins have been labelled in different periods as saintly, as witches, or as insane.

Survey of women as political actors: participation in political life, barriers to participation, political attitudes, issues of special concern to women, and issues of particular concern to women of color.
Role and status of women as depicted in the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament and the New Testament. The stories and laws concerning women found in the Bible and from extra-biblical evidence.

notes.div: May not be offered every year.

description.div: Representative works by Black women, composed in various genres, studied in their social and historical contexts.
Representative writings by Native American women in their social and historical contexts.

Surveys Black and/or African-American women's history from the 15th to the late 20th century. The transatlantic slave trade, "New World" experiences, slavery and resistance, sexuality, cultural persistence and evolution, racial strife, the struggle for civil rights, and black womanist and feminist theories.

History of the indigenous women of North America. Gender roles and kinship organization, women's work and economic activities, political and diplomatic roles, and everyday lives and relationships. Analysis of change over time and the effects of colonization and dominant society's imposition of patriarchy. Famous indigenous women such as: Pocahontas, Sacagewea, Nancy Ward, and Winona LaDuke. Contemporary issues.

course.title: History of Women and Gender in the American West

description.div: The effect of colonialism on women and gender in the American West.

course.title: Women and Work in USA History

description.div: Transformation of women's role in the USA economy from colonial times to the present and the effects of class, race, and changing perceptions of women's role in society. Role of women in household manufacture, the early factory system, the trade union movement, the Great Depression, the home front of WWII, and the economic emergence of women in the postwar economy.
The intersections of gender, identity, power, and representation throughout time and space in the Great Plains of the United States and Canada.
Survey on the literary production written by women in Europe, Asia, Africa and Latin America.
Historical roles of women as scientists. Societal constructs of gender in science. Feminist critiques of scientific methodology and interpretation.

course.title: Body Language: Love, Politics, and the Self in French Literature

description.div: French texts from the sixteenth to twentieth centuries (drama, prose, poetry, autobiography), all of which use the body as a reference point to explore developments in gender, religion, science, and society in French literature and civilization.

course.title: Special Topics in Women's & Gender Studies

description.div: Topics vary.

notes.div: Prior arrangement with and permission of Women's & Gender Studies faculty member.

description.div: Independent scholarship or other appropriate project with an individual Women's and Gender Studies faculty member.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing and permission; Candidate for degree with distinction or high distinction or highest distinction in the College of Arts and Sciences; Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

notes.div: Aimed primarily at Women's and Gender Studies majors and minors. Other students may take the course with permission.

description.div: Topic varies. Focus is to integrate a variety of perspectives on Women's and Gender Studies; to tie together diverse materials that the student will have been presented with in the discipline oriented courses.

course.title: Sexuality in Nineteenth and Twentieth Century America

description.div: Sexual practices and ideologies in American history from the 1800's to the present.

Theoretical approaches to gender. Emphasis is placed on cross-cultural differences in gender socialization of as it pertains to sexual behavior, power within domestic and public spheres, and the impact of gender on individual aspirations.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing; 3 hrs PSYC or SOCI; TMFD 123.

description.div: Theories and research findings about the social and psychological aspects of clothing and appearance in relation to the self and others.
A particular historical or other groups of literature by and about women, seen in their aesthetic and intellectual context.
Selected women writers from the twentieth and twenty-first century.

Theory and research on the role of gender in human behavior and attitudes. Diverse theoretical positions on the development of gender and the biological, social, and cultural bases that influence the relationship between gender and a variety of areas of human experience (e.g., intelligence and achievement, emotion, relationships, sexuality, physical fitness, stress, and coping).

course.title: Gender and Sexuality in the Ancient World

description.div: Ancient Greek and Roman evidence pertaining to the fields of women's studies, gender studies, and the study of sexuality.

course.title: Seminar in U.S. Women's and Gender History

description.div: In-depth, advanced thematic seminar that cultivates historical research and writing skills.

Introduction to the field of feminist economics. Critiques of economic theory and methodology along with gender and household decision-making, the care economy, international migration, development, globalization, the feminization of labor markets, and macroeconomics.

course.title: Working with GLBT Youth in Professional Contexts

description.div: To introduce contextual considerations and research-informed guidelines for working with Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, and Transgender youth in professional settings such as educational, mental health, medical, and community outreach. The systemic context of GLBT youth, including developmental transitions, unique stressors, peer relationships, and familial environments, will be explored. Ways to help GLBT youth thrive will be emphasized.

course.title: Women and Gender in African Societies

courseCode.subject: HIST
courseCode.courseGroup: Latin American, Asian, Middle Eastern or African History

description.div: Explores how the contemporary womenâs movement has emerged within Africa and its relationship to social change.

course.title: Rhetorical Theory: Rhetoric of Women Writers

description.div: Rhetoric and rhetorical theory of women writers and speakers and its implications for literature, composition, literacy, feminist theory, and women's and gender studies.

course.title: Gender and Sexuality in Latin America

courseCode.subject: HIST
courseCode.courseGroup: Latin American, Asian, Middle Eastern or African History

description.div: Experience of femininity and masculinity compared according to time and place, revealing the intimate connections with nation, modernity, race, and ethnicity.
Introduction to feminist and gender theory. Important theoretical frameworks upon which Women's Studies is based and the implications of these theories in practice.

Evaluation and application of scholarly theory and research on gender in societal context. The nature and effects of sex stratification, gendered culture, institutionalized sexism, feminist theory and sociology of knowledge.
Topics vary.

course.title: Internship in Women's and Gender Studies

description.div: Experiential and service learning designed to deepen understanding of classroom concepts related to study of women and gender in society.

course.title: Special Topics in Women's and Gender Studies

description.div: Topics vary.

course.title: Special Topics in Women's and Gender Studies

description.div: Advanced graduate level seminar in Women's and Gender Studies. Topics vary by semester.

course.title: Independent Study in Women's and Gender Studies

description.div: Individual or group study on a topic in Women's and Gender Studies under supervision and evaluation of a Women's and Gender Studies faculty member.
A comparative approach, offering readings on a central theme from a variety of periods and/or areas. Themes vary.
